text.0: Just as interactions between Black people and police outside the hospital put our patients at risk, so does their criminalization within the health care system, which can be particularly harmful in the context of pregnancy, childbearing, and reproductive health.
text.1: The NEJM Race and Medicine topic page features a selection of NEJM articles on race and medicine with implications for improving patient care, professional training, research, and public health. All articles assembled on the page are freely available.
text.2: Fundamentals of U.S. Health Policy: a series offering a primer on the main challenges facing our health care system and key policy solutions. With articles by @EricSchneiderMD, @amitabhchandra2, @evansmkt, @MattAFiedler, @Michael_Chernew
text.3: Menopausal #HormoneTherapy and risk for #BreastCancer: Clarifying the specifics: Most of the excess risk for breast cancer seen with hormone therapy relates to estrogen-progestin therapy. https://t.co/psJDSHhrlj https://t.co/x8nDg0U4y7
text.4: Members of the U.S. military are at risk for a range of combat-related injuries and hazardous exposures, and some chronic health problems can arise years after service. Although there have been important advances in our ability to care for veterans, challenges remain.
text.5: Prevention of falls in older people is important. In this pragmatic, cluster RCT, advice given by mail, screening for risk of falls, and targeted interventions for older people at increased risk for falls did not prevent fractures more than advice by mail alone.

text.7: In this audio interview conducted on November 4, 2020, the editors assess the current state of the U.S. response to Covid-19: vaccines, therapeutics, testing, and social interventions.
